intro: Corydalis crispa var. waltonii, commonly known as the Welsh poppy, is a member of the Fumariaceae family. It is a herbaceous perennial plant native to the mountainous regions of Wales and western England. The plant features slender, erect stems with lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its flowers are typically pink or purple, arranged in clusters and blooming in late spring to early summer. The plant is valued for its ornamental appeal and has been cultivated for its delicate, bell-shaped flowers.
